definition[0]: if soldiers or other people march somewhere, they walk there quickly with firm regular steps
note[0]: Quick march! (=an order to tell people to start marching)
example[0]: On 29 August the royal army marched into Inverness.
example[1]: We marched 50 km across the foothills.
example[2]: He gathered his troops and prepared to march on the capital  (=march to the capital in order to attack it).
definition[1]: if a large group of people march somewhere, they walk there together to express their ideas or protest about something
example[3]: An estimated 5,000 people marched through the city to demonstrate against the factory closures.
example[4]: Outraged citizens marched on City Hall  (=marched to City Hall), demanding the police chief’s resignation.
definition[2]: to walk somewhere quickly and with determination, often because you are angry
example[5]: Brett marched out of the office, slamming the door behind him.
definition[3]: to force someone to walk somewhere with you, often pushing or pulling them roughly
example[6]: Mr Carter marched us to the principal’s office.
definition[4]: an organized event in which many people walk together to express their ideas or protest about something
example[7]: The police decided not to ban the march.
example[8]: I went on a lot of peace marches when I was a student.
definition[5]: when soldiers walk with firm regular steps from one place to another
example[9]: The general led his forces on a long march southwards.
definition[6]: a piece of music for people to march to
definition[7]: the third month of the year, between February and April
example[12]: She started work here last March.
example[15]: I wrote to my bank on 6th March.
example[16]: The hospital is scheduled to open March 6.
